questions.text: You are asked to prescribe a cholinergic agent to a patient suffering from Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following drugs cannot be chosen?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist (not a cholinergic agent) indicated for the management of moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease.

Donepezil, galantamine, and tacrine are centrally acting cholinesterase inhibitors indicated for Alzheimer’s disease.

Note: In this scenario, you are asked to prescribe a cholinergic drug. Tacrine, a cholinergic drug, although hepatotoxic, is still approved for use in Alzheimer's disease. Hence, memantine is the best answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic CT appearance seen in patients with acute subdural hematoma?
questions.solution:
A crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines on axial CT is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
  • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections
  • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
  • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

A lentiform (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion that does not cross suture lines on axial CT is suggestive of an epidural hemorrhage.

The image given below shows a subdural hematoma with a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion on CT:

 

The image given below is that of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage seen on CT:

 

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.solution:

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with reports showing fungal pneumonia, the causative organism is shown below. Parents give a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Laboratory analysis show markedly elevated IgM and low levels of IgG. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his illness?

IgM: Immunoglobulin M

IgG: Immunoglobulin G

STAT 3: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3

NADPH: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate

choices.text: Defective cytokine signaling in T-cell precursors
Autosomal-dominant mutation in the STAT3 gene
Deficiency in CD40 ligand or CD40
Defect in the NADPH oxidative pathway

questions.solution:
The given history of recurrent bacterial infections and fungal pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (as shown in the image above), along with elevated IgM and low IgG levels, are suggestive of hyper-IgM syndrome, an inherited deficiency in the CD40 ligand or CD40.

Hyper-IgM syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder that is inherited as:

  • X-linked form (most common): CD40 ligand (CD40L) defect on T-helper cells, preventing B-cell activation, class switching and memory cells formation. 
  • Autosomal recessive form: Affect CD40 on B-cells or enzymes like activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme expressed in B cells. 

The B-cell response to T-independent antigen is unaffected. CD40–CD40L interactions are also required for IL-12 secretion. So, defects in this pathway result in increased susceptibility to intracellular pathogens.

In normal immune response, B-cells expressing CD40 on their surface interact with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM with extremely low levels of IgG and no IgA or IgE. 

Clinical features include recurrent pyogenic infections caused by low levels of opsonizing IgG antibodies. Patients are highly susceptible to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

The illustration below depicts the defects in components of T-cell & B-cell interactions that give rise to primary immunodeficiency.

Other options: 

Option A: Defective cytokine signalling in T-cell precursors is seen in X-linked Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID). It is caused by a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. This defect disrupts Interleukins (IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15 and IL-21) signalling, leading to low T-cell and NK-cell numbers. Although B-cell numbers are normal, these are non-functional due to the absence of T-cell help, resulting in impaired antibody synthesis. 

Option B: Mutation in the STAT3 gene is seen in an autosomal dominant form of Hyper IgE syndrome (also known as Job syndrome), characterized by recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent pulmonary infections often with pneumatoceles and atopic dermatitis. Here, serum IgE levels are markedly elevated (due to IgE overproduction without modulation), and IgA, IgG and IgM concentrations are generally normal. 

Option D: A defect in NADPH oxidative pathway is seen in chronic granulomatous disease, leading to failure of the oxidative burst in phagocytes, predisposing individuals to catalase-positive microbial infections.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed as a first-line drug for a patient with painful diabetic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

  • First-line: 
    • Lidoderm 5% patch
    • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
    • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
    • Duloxetine
  • Second-line: 
    • Carbamazepine
    • Phenytoin
    • Venlafaxine
    • Tramadol
  • Third-line:
    • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex does it represent?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus.

  • When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor reflexes are stimulated.
  • About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex.
  • After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex.

In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the after-discharge is smaller.

questions.text: A 1-day-old newborn developed severe sepsis and died after 1 day despite aggressive treatment. On examination, multiple granulomas are present over the skin. The organism isolated from the blood sample shows the motility depicted below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Early onset sepsis with skin granulomas and organisms showing tumbling motility points to a diagnosis of granulomatosis infantiseptica caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

Listeria monocytogenes shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25 °C. But at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C. This is known as differential motility as motility pattern changes with a change in temperature. Listeria moves from cell-to-cell using host cell actin framework.

Listeria infection can manifest as febrile gastroenteritis, bacteremia, neurolisteriosis and granulomatosis infantiseptica.

questions.text: You are evaluating a woman with unilateral facial weakness. However, you notice forehead wrinkling is intact. On examination, which of the following findings would you not expect?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion of the facial nerve in which the emotional response is affected. Patients with UMN lesions of the facial nerve have emotional incontinence i.e. involuntary, uncontrollable laughter, or crying with a paradoxical deficit of facial expression.

Normally cerebellum modulates motor outputs in response to sensory inputs. UMN facial palsy (type of pseudobulbar palsy) is associated with disruption of cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathways leading to loss of cerebellar modulation resulting in:

  • Emotional dysmetria (difficulty in fine-tuning emotional responses)
  • Emotional disinhibition (excessive emotional output)

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the major diagnostic triad of fat embolism syndrome (FES)?
questions.solution:
Fat globules in urine is a minor criterion in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome.

Fat embolism syndrome is caused by the release of fat globules from the bone marrow into the bloodstream. It usually occurs following long bone or pelvic fractures, and multiple fractures.

Along with platelet aggregates, the globules result in the following manifestations which make up the major diagnostic triad:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
  • Neurological impairment
  • Petechial rash

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: You are a first-year resident in the postpartum ward. During rounds, you see a 28-year-old woman who has been unable to breastfeed since delivery. Her baby was born by normal vaginal delivery that was complicated by severe postpartum hemorrhage. Her blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg and her pulse is 96/min. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome. Corticosteroids must be supplemented first, as life-threatening manifestations may occur due to the sudden onset of adrenal insufficiency. This is followed by the replacement of other deficient pituitary hormones including thyroid hormone and estrogen administered with or without progesterone.

questions.text: Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the ________.
questions.solution:
Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the occipital cortex.

Homonymous hemianopia involves vision loss on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. This type of visual field loss is suggestive of a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma in the visual pathway.

Complete homonymous hemianopia involves the complete visual hemifields of both eyes and can occur with any large enough lesion posterior to the optic chiasma. Visual field examination alone cannot further localize the lesion in such cases.

Incomplete homonymous hemianopia is due to smaller lesions in the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasm. They are further divided into congruous and incongruous depending on the extent to which the defects in the two half fields match each other exactly.

Because of a relative disorder among axon bundles in the immediate post-chiasmal region, diseases in this location produce rather incongruent lesions.

More posteriorly, the axon bundles of the corresponding areas of the two hemifields are more closely aligned and hence, lesions of the occipital cortex produce congruous homonymous hemianopia while incongruous homonymous hemianopia is more likely seen with optic tract lesions.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Granisetron was prescribed to a patient with gastrointestinal radiation syndrome to manage his symptoms. At what dose of radiation does this condition typically occur?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal radiation syndrome occurs after exposure of 600-1000 rad.

Acute radiation syndrome is characterized by three main presentations:

  1. Hematopoietic - marked by aplastic anemia. This occurs at 2–3 Gy or higher. This may result in infections, bleeding, and anemia due to the destruction of red blood cells. 
  2. Gastrointestinal - occurs due to absorbed doses of 6-7 Gy (600–1000 rad). The signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain. Symptomatic management is advised with intravenous ondansetron or oral granisetron. 
  3. Neurovascular - This syndrome typically occurs at absorbed doses greater than 30 Gy (3000 rad), though it may occur at 10 Gy (1000 rad). It presents with neurological symptoms such as dizziness, headache, or decreased level of consciousness, occurring within minutes to a few hours, and with an absence of vomiting. It is invariably fatal.

questions.text: A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with three episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for 3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible.

Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in pre-eclampsia.

PRES is characterized by the following:

  • Severe headaches
  • Altered sensorium
  • Seizures
  • Visual disturbances. 

Radiological findings in PRES:

  • Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes.
  • The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved.
  • Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in severe cases.

Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include:

  • Headaches 
  • Convulsions
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blindness 
  • Cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a patient with a dilated pupil not responsive to 1% pilocarpine?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate answer would be a pharmacological block. Antimuscarinic will occupy the receptors and results in non-responsiveness to pilocarpine.

In diabetic third nerve palsy, the dilated pupil is due to the loss of innervation to constrictor pupillae. Muscarinic receptors on constrictor pupillae will be intact resulting in miosis by pilocarpine.

In Adie's tonic pupil, there is denervation hypersensitivity. Pupil responds to even lower concentrations of pilocarpine.

Uncal herniation causes pressure on the third nerve leading to ipsilateral mydriasis. But muscarinic receptors are intact and thus the pupil responds to pilocarpine.

questions.text: Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of Purkinje cells.

It occurs in advanced cases of chronic alcoholism. There is a loss of Purkinje cells and proliferation of the adjacent astrocytes between the depleted granular cell layer and the molecular layer of the cerebellum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was rushed to the casualty of a maternity hospital due to imminent delivery. It resulted in a stillborn baby as shown in the picture below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an occipital bone defect with retroflexion of the neck and trunk, which is typical of iniencephaly. Inion is the tip of the external occipital protuberance and this defect comes under the spectrum of neural tube defects.

Diastematomyelia (Option A)  is a congenital disorder in which a part of the spinal cord is split, usually at the level of the upper lumbar vertebra.

Holoprosencephaly (Option D) occurs when the procencephalon fails to develop into two hemispheres.

questions.text: A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referred to ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection. Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?

questions.text: Which of the following patients with schizophrenia has the best prognosis?

choices.text: A 30-year-old with stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
A 20-year-old with disorganised thinking, flat affect with inappropriate emotions
A 35-year-old  with hallucinations, delusions of persecution and grandeur
A 25-year-old with insidious onset of negative symptoms without any hallucinations

questions.solution:
Patient with stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing suggests catatonic schizophrenia. It has the best prognosis among all types of schizophrenia.

Simple schizophrenia has the worst prognosis.

Types of schizophrenia:

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganized)

  • Early-onset
  • Disorganized behavior and thoughts, contact with reality is poor
  • Social behavior and their emotional responses are inappropriate
  • Bad prognosis
  • Term coined by Hecker

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, and control, etc
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • The alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

These subtypes were dropped in DSM V. In ICD-11, they are classified under the 'schizophrenia, episode unspecified' category, but may be removed.

questions.text: Indomethacin is associated with significant CNS adverse effects. The most frequent CNS adverse effect among the following is _______.
questions.solution:
The most frequent CNS adverse effect of indomethacin is a severe frontal headache. 

Dizziness, vertigo, light-headedness, and mental confusion can also occur, but the incidence is less. Rarely, indomethacin use is associated with seizures, severe depression, psychosis, hallucinations, and suicide. 

Clinical correlation-Cautious use of indomethacin in elderly patients and patients with a history of psychosis, depression, or epilepsy is required as they are at high risk of adverse CNS  effects.

questions.text: A patient recovering from COVID-19 presented with sudden onset slurred speech and difficulty walking. On examination, cerebellar signs are positive. What is true about the affected circuitry?

choices.text: Climbing and mossy fibers are inhibitory and use GABA as the neurotransmitter.
Mossy fibers end by forming a synapse with dendrites of Purkinje cells.
All climbing fibers originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus.
Efferent fibers from all the cerebellar nuclei leave the cerebellum through superior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute viral cerebellitis secondary to COVID-19. The true statement regarding the cerebellar circuitry is that that all climbing fibres originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus.

Option A: Climbing and mossy fibers are excitatory and use glutamate and aspartate as the neurotransmitters.

Option B: Mossy fibers terminate on the granule cells forming glomeruli. 

Option D: Efferents of the cerebellum pass through the superior and inferior cerebellar peduncles.

    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text:
Laboratory reports of a patient revealed an elevated serum potassium level. What is the classical sequence of ECG changes seen in this patient?
  1. Tall peaked T wave
  2. Loss of P wave
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
Elevated serum potassium level is called hyperkalemia. The classical sequence of ECG changes seen with increasing severity of hyperkalemia is option B - 1, 2, 3, 4.

Hyperkalemia is defined by serum K+ > 5.5mM. It usually manifests as a medical emergency with cardiac arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Note: These changes are particularly insensitive in patients with CKD.

questions.text: A person is caught in an airport for a case of smuggling of drugs. Suspecting that he has swallowed packets of cocaine, which of the following is the best modality to identify them?
questions.solution:
CT imaging is the best modality to identify cocaine packets in a body packer. 

Body packers are people who swallow a large number of well-sealed packets in order to smuggle drugs across international borders.

Body stuffers are patients who swallow cocaine following police pursuit to conceal the evidence. The swallowed packets are often poorly wrapped and can leak or perforate.

Both methods can result in severe toxicity and death.

Management:

  • No signs of toxicity - Give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to gently hasten packet elimination
  • Symptomatic patients - Provide sedation and symptomatic care, and obtain immediate surgical consultation for operative removal of the packets
  • Endoscopy or colonoscopy is not done because the manipulation may rupture the packets.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with progressive muscular weakness was posted for diagnostic muscle biopsy. Which of the following modes of induction is preferred?

choices.text: Inhalational induction with depolarizing muscle relaxant
Inhalational induction with nondepolarizing muscle relaxant
Intravenous induction with depolarizing muscle relaxant
Intravenous induction with nondepolarizing muscle relaxant

questions.solution:
The child most likely has muscular dystrophy, which makes him susceptible to malignant hyperthermia. Hence, the preferred mode of induction would be intravenous induction with a nondepolarizing muscle relaxant.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic (autosomal dominant) hypermetabolic muscle disease.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: While studying a spinal cord section, a pathology resident noted that the nuclei of the Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia were enlarged nearly 5 times the normal size. This finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In ataxia-telangiectasia, the nuclei of the Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia are enlarged to nearly 2-5 times the normal size. This finding is seen in the Schwann cells of dorsal root ganglia, peripheral nerves, endothelial cells, and pituicytes. These cells are called amphicytes.

Ataxia-telangiectasia is due to mutations of the ATM gene, located on chromosome 11q. It predominantly affects the cerebellum with the loss of Purkinje and granule cells. There is also degeneration of the dorsal columns, spinocerebellar tract, anterior horn cells, and peripheral neuropathy.

Telangiectatic lesions are found in the CNS as well as in the conjunctiva and skin of the face, neck, and arms.  The lymph nodes, thymus, and gonads are hypoplastic.

questions.text: A 41-year-old renal transplant patient developed nasal discharge, painful swelling, redness, and blurry vision of the right eye followed by a headache. A sinus biopsy specimen showed the following appearance on histology. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is strongly suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Biopsy confirms this diagnosis and differentiates it from the other listed organisms by revealing non-septate hyphae branching at right-angles, which are characteristic of Mucorales such as Rhizopus delemar.

Clinical suspicion based on the given symptoms in a diabetic/immunosuppressed individual should prompt immediate treatment with liposomal amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with chronic constipation, headache, neuromas of the tongue, medullated corneal nerve fibres and a nodule of 2*2 cm in the left lobe of the thyroid. Which of the following syndromes does the patient have?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. 

In MEN 2B, along with medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma, it is associated with other abnormalities such as mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon. Parathyroid tumours are generally not seen here, in contrast to the MEN 2A type.

Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN) describe conditions with tumours involving two or more endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN type 2 comprises groups of disorders caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2. There are three variants:

  • MEN 2A, also known as MEN 2 (most common type)
  • MEN 2B, also known as MEN 3
  • MTC only

MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It is characterised by medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumours.

  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma

questions.text: A screening test is used in the same way in two similar populations. But, the proportion of false-positive results among those who test positive in population A is higher than that among those who test positive in population B. What is the likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: The specificity of the test is lower in population A.
The prevalence of the disease is lower in population A.
The prevalence of the disease is higher in population A.
The specificity of the test is higher in population A.

questions.solution:
The prevalence of the disease is lower in population A.

The contingency table for a test is given as:

  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive a (True Positive) b (False Positive)
Test negative c (False Negative) d (True Negative)

Since, positive predictive value (PPV) = (a/a+b) x 100

Hence, PPV is inversely related to a false-positive rate.

In the above case scenario, the false-positive rate is higher in population A, so the PPV in population A will be lower. Now, since PPV is directly proportional to prevalence, this means prevalence will be lower in population A.

 

Note: Sensitivity and specificity are the properties of a test, and they do not vary with the population.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following neural mechanism is not involved in synaptic plasticity and learning?
questions.solution:
Sensitization is a neural mechanism involved in synaptic plasticity and learning (not desensitization).

Neural basis of synaptic plasticity and learning

  • Post-tetanic Potentiation
    • Production of enhanced postsynaptic potential, which occurs after a brief tetanizing train of stimuli in the presynaptic neuron
    • This enhancement lasts up to 60 seconds.
  • Habituation
    • A simple form of learning in which neutral stimulus is repeated many times until the subject becomes habituated to the stimulus and ignores it
    • A classic example of non-associative learning (e.g., learning a fact by heart)
  • Sensitization: The opposite of habituation
  • Long-term Potentiation (LTP)
    • A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • Characteristically observed in the hippocampus
  • Long-term Depression
    • Is the opposite of LTP
    • Characterized by a decrease in synaptic strength
    • Produced by slower stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • May be involved in the neural mechanism by which learning occurs in the cerebellum

questions.text: A 62-year-old known hypertensive woman presented to the emergency with spasticity of both lower limbs. Further neurological examination showed regular, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of a muscle subjected to sudden, maintained stretch. Which of the following is false regarding this phenomenon?

choices.text: Only sustained clonus with five or more beats is considered abnormal
Clonus may also occur in spinal cord injury that disrupts the descending cortical input to a spinal glycinergic inhibitory interneuron called the Renshaw cell
The stretch reflex–inverse stretch reflex sequence may contribute to this response
This is characteristic of states in which decreased γ-motor neuron discharge is present

questions.solution:
The case scenario indicates clonus. A characteristic of states in which increased γ-motor neuron discharge is present is clonus. 

All the other options are correct.

When a muscle is subjected to a sudden and maintained stretch, there occur regular, repetitive, and rhythmic contractions. This is called clonus. Ankle clonus is a typical example.

questions.text: After assessing a young child treated for unilateral retinoblastoma, you note significant delays in the cognitive and fine motor domains. The baby can stand without support and creep well. Normally, the highest fine motor skill a baby of this age is expected to have is ________

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer grasp is seen at 9 months. Child begins to scribble after 15 months.

Fine motor development is critically linked with hand-eye coordination. Children who have disease-related loss of vision in early infancy develop difficulties in visuomotor integration and lags behind in fine motor milestones.

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that children be screened at 18 and 24 months or whenever a parent or provider has a concern. Milestone tracker apps are being used by the parents to monitor the development of their child.

questions.text: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the perceived sound?
questions.solution:
The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting the direction from which a sound comes.

The eighth nerves reach their respective cohlear nuclei in the medulla from where the nerves travel to both the ipsilateral and contralteral superior olivary nuclei in the pons and hence giving it the ability to detect the direction of the sound.

The lateral part of superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the time lag between the signals entering the two ears.

questions.text: The two elevations on the medial wall of the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle are due to _______.

choices.text: Tapetum of the corpus callosum and calcar avis

questions.solution:
The two elevations on the medial wall of the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle are due to the forceps major and calcar avis. 

The posterior horn extends from the splenium to the occipital pole. The relations are: 

  • Roof and lateral wall - Tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

The forceps major is the fibers of the splenium of the corpus callosum.

The calcar avis is formed by the white matter of the calcarine sulcus.

Forceps minor is formed by the anterior part of the corpus callosum.

The collateral eminence is formed by the collateral sulcus and is related to the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: The image shows certain changes in the conjunctiva commonly found in a DNA repair defect syndrome. What is the first clinical manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple telangiectasias of conjunctival vessels. This along with DNA repair defect point towards ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) or Louis–Bar syndrome. Progressive cerebellar degeneration is the first clinical manifestation in ataxia-telangiectasia, presenting at about 1 year of age.

AT is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder. There is chromosomal instability due to inactivating mutations in the ATM gene. The ATM protein kinase plays a key role in the control of double-strand break DNA repair.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by ataxia and mucocutaneous telangiectasia. Cutaneous features include: 

  • Telangiectasias - initially conjunctival, most prominent on face
  • Premature hair greying
  • Café‐au‐lait spots
  • Pigmentary changes - poikiloderma.

Other cardinal features of AT are:

  • Immunodeficiency - increased susceptibility to infections
  • Hypogonadism
  • Sensitivity to ionizing radiation
  • Insulin resistance
  • Predisposition to cancer

questions.text: A horse-groomer was diagnosed with ulcerative tracheobronchitis. Upon enquiry, it was discovered that one of his horses had recently died of pneumonia after developing a fever and subcutaneous nodules. Which of the following statements is false about the likely causative agent?

choices.text: It is the causative agent for Glanders disease.
It induces Strauss reaction on inoculation into guinea pigs.

questions.solution:
The development of ulcerative tracheobronchitis after contact with an infected horse is suggestive of glanders which is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is an oxidase variable organism.

In this case, the horse likely had glanders, which presents with fever, pneumonia, and subcutaneous nodules called Farcy buds. Discharges from the respiratory tract and skin are highly infectious and can be transmitted to humans through close contact (occupational route). The horse-groomer likely contracted the infection by the inhalational route and developed acute glanders, which is characterised by fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge and ulcerative necrosis of upper respiratory tract (ulcerative tracheobronchitis). It may lead to septicemia and has a high fatality rate. Percutaneous exposure causes local suppurative skin lesions with associated regional lymphadenopathy.

B. mallei is a non-motile Gram-negative bacillus causing Glanders disease. It is an aerobe and a facultative anaerobe. It is oxidase variable i.e. it is usually oxidase negative but may occasionally show a positive reaction. It is a biosafety level 3 pathogen and so must be handled only in specialised laboratories. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with suspected infectious material, it causes Strauss reaction. B. mallei sets up a necrotizing inflammation in the scrotal sac within a few days and can be confirmed bacteriologically.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions show ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema are seen in Foster–Kennedy syndrome.

Weber syndrome (superior alternating hemiplegia) is a form of stroke characterized by the presence of an ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia.

Millard–Gubler syndrome is a lesion of the pons. It is also called ventral pontine syndrome.

Benedikt syndrome, also known as paramedian midbrain syndrome, involves the fasciculus of oculomotor nerve as it passes through the red nucleus and is characterized by ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs such as hemitremor.

Related Pearl: Foster–Kennedy Syndrome

  • It is characterized by the occurrence of:
    • Ipsilateral pressure optic atrophy and
    • Contralateral papilledema (due to raised intracranial pressure).
  • It is associated with olfactory or sphenoidal meningiomata and frontal lobe tumors.

Pseudo-Foster–Kennedy syndrome: It is characterized by the occurrence of:

  • Pre-existing optic atrophy due to any cause on one eye.
  • Unilateral papilledema associated with raised intracranial pressure due to some other cause on the opposite side.

questions.text: Which of the following blood components does not carry the risk of transmitting cytomegalovirus infection?

    • Platelet concentrates stored at room temperature: gram-positive and coagulase-negative staphylococci
    • PRBCs: Gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia, Pseudomonas, Serratia, Acinetobacter, and Escherichia species
  • Parasites: Malaria, Babesiosis, Chaga's disease

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby presented with seizures, developmental delay and failure to thrive. Following an MRI, a diagnosis of a neuronal migration disorder was made. What is the probable diagnosis?

Neuronal migration is the process during brain development, where the neuronal cells migrate to their proper designated site by various mechanisms, to form the 6-layered cerebral cortex. Any abnormality in the above process leads to neuronal migration defects.

Myelomeningocele (Option B) is a neural tube defect that occurs due to defective closure of the neural tube.

questions.text: In a clinical trial, what would be the best study design that ensures comparability between experimental and control groups?
questions.solution:
A cross-over study would be the best method to ensure comparability between the experimental and control group.

In a cross over study design, patients are randomly assigned to the study and control group, and then after a period of time, their groups are switched. Here, each patient serves as his/her own control which allows for maximum comparability.

In a concurrent parallel study design, comparisons are made between two randomly assigned groups and there is no switching of groups. This allows only for limited comparability between experimental and control groups.

Quasi-experiments are studies that aim to evaluate interventions but that do not use randomization. The lack of randomisation is the major weakness of quasi trials. The comparability in a quasi trial is limited.

A per-protocol analysis is a comparison of treatment groups that include only those patients who completed the treatment originally allocated. Hence, comparability is limited.

questions.text: In a population of 9000 people, 2100 are alcoholics. 70 alcoholics and 23 non-alcoholics developed cirrhosis. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 90%.

Number of people exposed (to alcohol) = 2100 
Number of people not exposed (to alcohol) = 6900 

Incidence of cirrhosis among exposed = 70/2100 (IExposed)
Incidence of cirrhosis among non-exposed = 23/6900 (INon-exposed)

Attributable risk (AR) = [ ( IExposed - INon-exposed) / IExposed ]*100
= [ (70/2100 - 23/6900) / (70/2100)] *100
= [ 9 / 10 ] *100
= 90

Thus, the attributable risk (AR) is 90%.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn is suggestive of occult spinal dysraphism or neural tube defect. It comprises a range of conditions, including spina bifida occulta, intradural lipoma, and dorsal dermal sinus.

Spinal dysraphism is due to the defective fusion of the midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures. Associated clinical features are high-arched feet, muscle size and strength differences between legs, and abnormal walking patterns. In newborns and young infants, the neurological examination is usually normal, but older children may experience a lack of sensation in the perineal area and back pain.

Most of the patients will have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, including a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma.

The image shows a tuft of hair in a case of spinal dysraphism:

Spinal dysraphism also includes meningocele, myelomeningocele, lipomeningocele, diastematomyelia (split spinal cord), thickened filum terminale, and cauda equina tumour.

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

Spina bifida is the most common type of spinal dysraphism, in which the spinal column does not close completely, leaving the spinal cord and its protective covering exposed.

Myelomeningocele is the most severe form of spina bifida, where the spinal cord and nerve roots are exposed and may be damaged. A sac-like protrusion, containing spinal cord tissue, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid, is visible outside the body, often leading to significant neurological impairments and disabilities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about mesial temporal lobe epilepsy?

A family history of epilepsy is commonly present in patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following branches of the middle cerebral artery might be involved in a left-handed patient whose response to the question “what kind of work do you do ?” is “ We, all of us, this thing happened, we were working for a long time, it’s a space. If you had said that, it was fortunate to, mereate the building and grass the mawn.”?
questions.solution: The patient in question has Wernicke’s or sensory aphasia. Wernicke’s area in present in the posterior segment of the superior temporal gyrus. This is supplied by the inferior division of the MCA. Language is controlled by the dominant hemisphere. Left hemisphere is the dominant hemisphere in right-handed people and in majority of left-handed people as well. Hence, left inferior division of MCA is affected in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle highlighted in green in the image?
questions.solution:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the cerebellum. 

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates on the same side as its origin.

questions.text: During the neurological examination of a patient, you notice an abnormality while testing the visual field using confrontation field testing. On wiggling the index finger of one hand, the patient sees normally and reports the correct side but on wiggling fingers of both sides simultaneously, he only observes the right side and reports the left hand to be stationary. This is called ______.
questions.solution:
• The defect mentioned above is called visual inattention, also known as hemispatial neglect. It is the inability to report, respond, or orient to stimuli in one half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.
  • Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect: simultaneous bilateral stimulation (described above) and visual target cancellation.
  • In simultaneous bilateral stimulation, when the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory, or tactile modalities, patients have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side but perceive the bilaterally presented stimulus as coming only from one side. This phenomenon is known as extinction.
  • In visual target cancellation, the patient fails to detect the targets on one half of the field in target-detection tasks.

Option B: Simultanagnosia is the inability to integrate the visual information at the center of gaze with more peripheral information. These patients can only see one object at a time and sometimes only parts of an object despite having normal visual acuity. The objects seen by them cannot be located in space because they do not see anything else that can be used as a reference point.

Option C: Somatoparaphrenia is a phenomenon wherein the patient considers the paralytic hand to be a part of or belonging to someone else.

questions.text: A patient has normal right gaze. On attempting left gaze, his left eye abducts, but his right eye fails to adduct. The lesion is most likely in the _______.
questions.solution:
The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and runs to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). Output from the left PPRF runs to the left VI nerve nucleus supplying the left lateral rectus, causing abduction of the left eye. Output from the left PPRF also goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing right eye adduction.

Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: Phantogeusia refers to _______.

choices.text: Perception of taste in the absence of tastant
Perception of taste after amputation of tongue

questions.text: Witzelsucht refers to ________.

choices.text: Involuntary repetition of another person’s actions

questions.solution:
• Witzelsucht is a term used for inappropriate humor where lewd jokes and socially unacceptable puns are used in inappropriate places.
  • This is also called as an inappropriate jocular affect.
  • This can be seen in patients with the emotional disorder called pathological laughing and crying (PLAC).
  • The extreme of these emotions can be elicited in some patients by something as small as a wave of the hand by the examiner.
  • Witzelsucht can be localized to the right-hemispheric lesions, especially when involving the frontal lobe.

Other options:

Option B: Social disinhibition is a blanket term that refers to a lack of restraint and disregard for social conventions, boundaries and etiquette. It also involves poor risk assessment.

Option C: Involuntary repetition or imitation of another’s action is called echopraxia which can be seen in Tourette’s syndrome.

Option D: Akinetic mutism is the absence of voluntary motor movement and speech in an otherwise alert patient. It is seen in psychotic depression and catatonic states.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with Parkinson’s disease experiences difficulty in initiating movements, which has not improved despite trying multiple medications. She is referred for possible ablation surgery. Into which of the following structures should an ablative lesion be introduced to improve this patient’s bradykinesia?
questions.solution:
Structure 3 is globus pallidus internal. Ablation of this structure can improve symptoms of bradykinesia in this patient.

Considering the nigrostriatal pathway, the direct pathway stimulates movement and the indirect pathway inhibits movement.

The direct pathway starts from substantia nigra pars compacta, which stimulates the striatum to release GABA. GABA, being an inhibitory transmitter, inhibits globus pallidus internal. This prevents globus pallidus internal from itself releasing GABA. Thus the inhibition over thalamus is lifted and thalamus stimulates the cortex to produce motion.

The indirect pathway starts from substantia nigra pars compacta, which stimulates the striatum to release GABA. This GABA inhibits globus pallidus external. The inhibition that globus pallidus external exerts on subthalamic nucleus is lifted. The subthalamic nucleus stimulates globus pallidus internal to release GABA. This GABA inhibits thalamus which in turn cannot stimulate the cortex to produce motion.

Therefore, ablation of globus pallidus internal can disinhibit the thalamus thus improving this patient’s symptoms.

Structure 1: Thalamus

Structure 2: Globus pallidus external

Structure 4: Substantia nigra

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and gout presents with a 3-week history of progressive pain in his shoulders and hips and has difficulty reaching objects in his tall kitchen cabinets and has noticed the need to use his arms when rising from a chair. Pain and inability to reach tall kitchen cabinets and the necessity to use her arms when rising from a chair indicates proximal muscle weakness and myopathy.

Lisinopril does not cause myopathy.

Colchicine, amiodarone, and niacin are all known to be associated with drug-induced myopathy.

questions.text: The phenotypic variant of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease-1 that presents with postural tremor, gait ataxia along with distal muscle atrophy, pes cavus, and mild distal sensory loss is ______.
questions.solution:
The phenotypic variant of Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease-1 that presents with postural tremor, gait ataxia along with distal muscle atrophy, pes cavus, and mild distal sensory loss is Roussy–Levy syndrome.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease-1 (CMT1) is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy with the autosomal dominant form on inheritance. It is caused by mutations in genes that are expressed in Schwann cells.

Patients present in the first to third decade of life. Early complaints include frequent sprained ankles due to distal muscle weakness and difficulty in running. Footdrop, pes cavus, distal lower muscle atrophy, and areflexia are the physical findings seen. Due to the distal calf muscle atrophy, inverted champagne bottle legs or stork leg deformity is seen. Although the patients do not complain of sensory loss, reduced sensation to all modalities is seen on examination.

CMT1A: Most common subtype of CMT1. It is caused by a duplication or point mutation on PMP22 gene on chromosome 17. Duplication leads to three copies of the PMP22 gene, whereas point mutation alters the distribution of the protein.

CMT1B: also known as peroneal muscular atrophy is caused by point mutations in the gene encoding myelin protein zero (MPZ) on chromosome 1. Myelin protein zero is normally expressed on the cell membrane of Schwann cells, and it plays a major role in myelin membrane adhesion. Overexpression of this protein due to mutations is deleterious.

Roussy–Levy syndrome is a CMT1 phenotype that presents with postural tremor, gait ataxia, distal muscle atrophy, pes cavus, areflexia, and mild distal sensory loss.

Other options:

Option A: Dejerine–Sottas syndrome is a severe demyelinating neuropathy that presents in early infancy with hypotonia. It is classified under CMT3. It is characterized by delayed motor development, prominent sensory loss, and distal weakness, followed by proximal weakness and absent reflexes. The nerve conduction velocities (NCVs) are typically slowed to ≤10 m/sec. Scoliosis and contractures progressively develop over time.

Option B: Dejerine–Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome, arises due to the occlusion of the thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches of the P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA). It is characterized by contralateral hemisensory loss, which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions. This pain responds very poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) may be beneficial.

Option D: Cowchock syndrome is a form of infantile-onset axonal X-linked CMT presenting with deafness and mental retardation in males. It is caused by mutations in the apoptosis-inducing factor mitochondria-associated 1 (AIFM1) gene. Females have only minor abnormalities.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman working in a night-shift call center presents with complaints of generalized weakness and fatigue since the past 2 years that has progressively become worse. She says it gets worse towards the morning, and she feels better in the evenings. She also reports that her eyes feel heavy, and she finds it difficult to keep them open. Which of the following condition is most commonly associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above suggests a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. It is associated with thymoma.

The patient experiences generalized weakness, which progresses and becomes worse over the day for her. Since she works in a call center having night working hours, her weakness getting worse by the morning suggests weakness that gets worse over the day. This suggests a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

In contrast, weakness associated with Lambert–Eaton syndromes gets better over the day. This is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung.

  • Dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution)
  • Preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk

Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Nothnagel’s syndrome has ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia.
Foville’s syndrome has contralateral facial palsy.

questions.solution:
Claude’s syndrome has contralateral tremors.

Claude’s syndrome consists of ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy with contralateral cerebellar signs and contralateral tremor, athetosis, and chorea. It occurs due to injury to red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle.

Other options:

Option A: Nothnagel’s syndrome consists of ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral cerebellar ataxia. It occurs due to injury to the superior cerebellar peduncle.

Option B: Benedikt’s syndrome consists of ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy with contralateral tremor, chorea, and athetosis. It occurs due to injury to the red nucleus.

Option D: Foville’s syndrome consists of lateral gaze palsy, ipsilateral facial palsy, and contralateral hemiparesis. It occurs after dorsal pontine injury.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has shown benefit in the prevention of migraine?
questions.solution:
Framanezumab has shown benefit in episodic migraine.

Framanezumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP); it is effective is the prevention of episodic migraine. The recommended dose is 225 mg once monthly or 675 mg every three months, given subcutaneously in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm.

Erenumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits CGRP receptor; it has been shown to be effective in the prevention of episodic migraine.

Other options:

Option A: Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody against the RSV F glycoprotein that is used for the prevention of RSV lower respiratory tract disease in children at high risk of RSV disease.

Option B: Elotuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against SLAMF7, a glycoprotein expressed in multiple myeloma cells and natural killer cells. It is used in combination with lenalidomide and dexamethasone for the treatment of multiple myeloma. It is administered weekly for the first two 28-day cycles and then every two weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. This regimen requires prophylaxis against thromboembolism and infusion reactions. Patients have to be premedicated with dexamethasone, diphenhydramine, ranitidine, and acetaminophen.

Option D: Vedolizumab is anti-alpha-4-beta-7-integrin monoclonal antibody that’s used in Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not independently alter GABA-A receptor channel function?
questions.solution:
Flumazenil does not independently alter the GABA-A receptor channel function. 

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at benzodiazepine receptors on the GABA-A receptor channel. It has no independent action of its own.

Options A and C: 

  • Benzodiazepines increase the frequency of chloride channel opening, whereas beta-carboline decreases the frequency by binding to benzodiazepine (BZD) receptors on the GABA-A receptor channel. 
  • Flumazenil only competes with benzodiazepines (agonist) and beta-carboline (inverse agonist) for binding.

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drug use requires ophthalmological consultation?
questions.solution:
Topiramate is known to cause glaucoma, and use of topiramate requires ophthalmological consultation.

The systemic side effects of topiramate are as follows:

  • Renal stones
  • Glaucoma
  • Weight loss
  • Hypohidrosis

questions.text: Which of the following signs is shown in the MRI image below?
questions.solution:
The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers, which are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location).

They are a relatively specific sign for multiple sclerosis and present as T2 hyperintensities.

MRI is the study of choice in imaging multiple sclerosis because of its greater sensitivity than CT in demonstrating plaques, both in the brain and spinal cord.

Other options:

  • Black hole lesions are multiple sclerosis plaques in the chronic stage when they display T1 hypointense signal that signifies axonal destruction and irreversible damage.
  • The molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth, seen in Joubert syndrome.
  • Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge–Weber Syndrome.

questions.text: In patients with trigeminal neuralgia, the nerve is most commonly compressed by ______.
questions.solution:
The superior cerebellar artery most often compresses the trigeminal nerve as it emerges from the brainstem. This causes lancinating pain in the distribution of the nerve which is known as trigeminal neuralgia.

Though trigeminal neuralgia can be diagnosed by the clinical features, MRI is recommended to define the underlying cause. In cases refractory to medical management, it also helps to plan for surgical decompression.

questions.text: A patient with neurofibromatosis 1 is found to have multiple tumors above the level of the lumbar spine. Which of the following is an early feature of dysautonomia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The early feature of dysautonomia that can occur in this patient is spastic bladder. 

Dysautonomia due to brain and spinal cord disease above the level of the lumbar spine results first in increased urinary frequency and small bladder volume. Eventually, incontinence occurs. These features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion, i.e., spastic bladder.

On the other hand, dysautonomia due to peripheral nervous system (PNS) disease of autonomic nerve fibers results in large bladder volumes, increased urinary frequency, and overflow incontinence. These are features suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion, i.e., flaccid bladder.

Postvoidal residual volume helps to distinguish between upper and lower motor neuron bladder dysfunction in the early stages of dysautonomia.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years. CSF cytology during each episode showed lymphocytic pleocytosis. Which organism is most commonly implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent episodes of lymphocytic meningitis, known as Mollaret's meningitis, is most commonly caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). 

Mollaret’s meningitis is characterized by recurrent episodes of aseptic lymphocytic meningitis that last for a few days, followed by symptom-free intervals. During an episode, patients present with fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea, vomiting, photophobia and neurological symptoms. Demonstration of HSV antibodies in CSF or persistence of HSV DNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Machado-Joseph disease?

choices.text: The mean age of onset is 25 years
Type III MJD is also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis- parkinsonism-dystonia type
Patients usually have normal intellectual function
Pathologically, sparing of inferior olives differentiates it from other dominant ataxias

questions.solution:
Type III is also known as ataxic–amyotrophic type.

Machado–Joseph disease or spinocerebellar type 3 has a mean age of onset at 25 years. It has 3 types:

  • Type I: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis- parkinsonism-dystonia type
  • Type II: Ataxic type
  • Type III: Ataxic–amyotrophic type

Patients usually have a normal intellectual function.

Pathologically: Loss of neurons in the corpus striatum, pars compacta of the substantia nigra, the dentate nucleus of the cerebellum, and the red nucleus is seen. Loss of Purkinje cells and granular cells are also seen in the cerebellar cortex. Sparing of inferior olives distinguishes it from other dominantly inherited ataxias.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding ataxia telangiectasia?

choices.text: Presents in 4th to 5th decade of life.
Increased incidence of lymphomas is seen

questions.solution:
Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive condition presenting in the first decade of life.

It is associated with a high incidence of recurrent pulmonary infections, lymphomas, Hodgkin's disease, breast cancer, and acute T cell leukemias.

Histology shows loss of Purkinje cells, granules, and basket cells in the cerebellar cortex. There is a loss of neurons in the deep cerebellar nuclei, inferior olives of the medulla, and anterior horn and dorsal root of the spinal cord.

Clinical features of ataxia-telangiectasia include:

  • Progressive telangiectatic lesions
  • Oculomotor apraxia 
  • Truncal and limb ataxia
  • Dysarthria
  • Extensor plantar reflexes 
  • Myoclonic jerks 
  • Areflexia 
  • Distal sensory deficits 
  • Nystagmus 
  • Cellular and humoral immunodeficiency (absent/ill-developed thymus)

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive atrophy and weakness of his hands and forearms. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and brisk jaw jerk. Neuroimaging revealed increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2 weighted MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). 

The clinical hallmark of ALS is the presence of signs and symptoms of both upper and lower motor neuron (UMN + LMN) dysfunction. The signs of UMN dysfunction include spasticity and brisk jaw jerk, while the signs of LMN dysfunction include atrophy and weakness of limbs.

Conventional MRI is usually normal in ALS and is used to exclude other possible causes although increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI is supportive of the diagnosis of ALS.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of Riluzole?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Where is the cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil?
questions.solution:
The cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil lies at the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8–T1).

The sympathetic pathway to the iris muscles consists of a chain of three neurons:

  • The first neuron arises from the hypothalamus along the brain stem to synapse in the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord—the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8-T1).
  • From here (C8-T1), the second-order neuron arises. This joins the cervical sympathetic chain and synapses at the superior cervical ganglion.
  • The third-order neuron arises from the superior cervical ganglion and travels through the cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.

Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. 

Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum. 

Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration ≤ 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving ≥ one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours ≥ 80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.

World Stroke Day is on October 29 every year. On this day, people everywhere share important information about recognizing the signs of a stroke, how to stay healthy, and ways to prevent strokes. The theme this year, as designated by WSO, is ‘Together we are #Greater Than Stroke.’ In India, the average stroke incidence rate is 145 per 1,00,000 population.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: The most common extradural spinal tumor is _________.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basilar skull fractures?

choices.text: Racoon eyes is one of the earliest signs to develop
Battle sign is associated with posterior cranial fossa fractures
CSF leaks should be promptly managed by surgical intervention
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided

questions.solution:
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided in patients with basilar skull fractures due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: “Halo” sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk for pneumocephalus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with back pain radiating to the leg after lifting a heavy suitcase. There is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, and great toe. The medial hamstring reflex is diminished. The knee and ankle jerks are normal. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case scenario is L4-L5 disc prolapse.

The points given in the question in favor of this diagnosis are back pain radiating to the leg, sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, great toe, diminished medial hamstring reflex, and normal ankle jerk. 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD) usually presents in adults between 20 to 40 years. The most common symptom is low back pain. It can be associated with or without pain radiating down the back of the leg (sciatica). 

Neurological features of L4-L5 PIVD are: 

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexor muscles of the foot
  • Sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe. One or more adjacent toes may also be involved (i.e., 1st web space) but never the little toe
  • Diminished medial hamstring reflex
  • Knee jerk and ankle jerk are normal.

Tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT): 

This test is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in a neutral position. Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. SLRT test negative if the leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain. SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal. Lasègue's test is a modified SLRT where the knee is bent to 90 degrees. 

2. Crossed straight-leg test: 

SLRT on the unaffected side. Pain felt on the affected side and is termed as contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is often highly specific for a large central prolapse. 

3. Bowstring sign or popliteal compression test: 

This test is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. It is performed by eliciting SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Now without reducing the amount of lift, the knee is bent to relax the sciatic nerve. The pain in the buttocks is immediately relieved. Following this, the popliteal fossa is pressed to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain. 

MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest, heat, ice, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants and/or spinal traction are commonly advised
  • Operative removal of the prolapsed disc: 
    • Absolute indication - cauda equina compression syndrome 
    • Relative indications - neurological deterioration, persistent pain and/or failed conservative treatment
