questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his etCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
A drastic fall in etCO2 with hypotension during neck surgery is most likely due to venous air embolism (VAE).

In modified radical neck dissection (MRND), a head-up position is given to provide a bloodless surgical field. VAE into severed vessels is likely to occur when the surgical site is above the right atrium and venous pressure at the incision site is below the atmospheric pressure. Pulmonary artery pressure will rise and etCO2 will fall after a venous air embolism.

In sympathetic overactivity and carotid body stimulation, blood pressure will rise.

In vagal stimulation, a drastic drop in etCO2 is unlikely.

 

This is a recent AIIMS question. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following features is required to diagnose a patient with pituitary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma:

  • A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites (and/or)
  • Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumour 

Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating mutations of the HRAS oncogene.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding firearm injury to the skull?

choices.text: The entry wound is wider on the inner table

questions.solution:
Exit wounds on the skull are wider on the outer table. 

Entry and exit wound on the skull:

Where several bullets have struck the cranium, the sequence of shots can usually be determined using Puppe’s rule. It is applicable to any multiple blunt force causing skull fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following head injury patients need not undergo head CT at this point in time?

choices.text: An RTA victim with GCS score of 12
A patient with an episode of vomiting
A child with an episode of seizure post-trauma
A biker with suspected skull fracture

questions.solution:
A single episode of vomiting after a head injury is not an indication for immediate CT brain. However, more than one episode mandates a scan.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following is the first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?
questions.solution:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.

It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.

Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).

The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

questions.text: Following nerve injury, how long will it take for the injured nerve to regenerate 1 cm?
questions.solution:
The injured nerve regenerates at the rate of 1 mm per day. Hence, it takes 10 days for it to acheive 1 cm regeneration.

As regeneration begins, the axonal stump from the proximal segment begins to grow distally. If the endoneural tube with its contained Schwann cells is intact, the axonal sprout may readily pass along its primary course and re-innervate the end organ.

The muscle nearest to the site of injury recovers first, followed by others as the nerve re-innervates muscles from proximal to distal, the so-called motor march.

questions.text: Floating teeth is seen in ________.
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of floating teeth is seen in Le Fort I fracture.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: The urinary bladder shown in the MCU image below is diagnostic of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows pine cone bladder or Christmas tree bladder, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall. It is typically seen in severe neurogenic bladder.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination.

There are five types of neurogenic bladder based on the site of the lesion.

  1. Sensory neurogenic bladder: Posterior columns of the spinal cord or afferent tracts leading from the bladder
  2. Motor paralytic bladder: Damage to motor neurons of the bladder
  3. Uninhibited neurogenic bladder: Incomplete spinal cord lesions above s2 or cerebral cortex or cerebropontine axis lesions
  4. Reflex neurogenic bladder: Complete spinal cord lesions above s2 - may lead to pine cone bladder
  5. Autonomous neurogenic bladder: Conus or cauda equina lesions

 

Note:

Occasionally, Christmas tree bladder is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with cauda equina syndrome?
questions.solution:
In cauda equina syndrome, the knee jerk is lost.

Causes for cauda equina syndrome include:

  • Pott's disease
  • Protrusion of disc

Initially, there is saddle-shaped hyperesthesia and later anesthesia involving buttocks, anus, and perineum. Along with this, there is flaccid paralysis below the knee and ankle reflex is lost. Bulbocavernosus reflex is also absent.

questions.text: A patient’s blood pressure is 120/60 mmHg and the intracranial pressure(ICP) reading is 30 mmHg. What is the cerebral perfusion pressure?
questions.solution:
The cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the difference between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP) (or central venous pressure if CVP>ICP).

MAP = Diastolic blood presssure (DBP)+ ⅓  Pulse pressure or

       = DBP+⅓ (SBP-DBP)

       = 80 mmHg

CPP = 80 (MAP) - 30(ICP)

      = 50 mmHg

Clearly, CPP will be affected by anything that changes the MAP or ICP.

  • Blood loss causing hypotension will reduce MAP and CPP (hence the reduced level of consciousness seen in severely shocked patients), while an intracerebral hematoma will increase ICP, with the same effect.

Due to cerebral autoregulation, cerebral blood flow remains constant with a CPP between 60-160 mmHg.

  • CPP < 60 mmHg will lead to ischemia
  • CPP > 160 mmHg will lead to edema/hemorrhage

questions.text: In the surgery performed for the treatment of temporal lobe epilepsy secondary to mesial temporal sclerosis, the following structures are removed except ___________.
questions.solution:
Surgical treatment for temporal lobe epilepsy is anterior temporal lobectomy, which does not include resection of the caudate nucleus.

Structures resected in anterior temporal lobectomy:

  • First few centimeters of anterior temporal lobe
    • 4.5 cm from the temporal tip in the language-dominant hemisphere
    • 6 cm from the temporal tip in the language non-dominant hemisphere
  • Amygdala
  • Head of the hippocampus

The complications of anterior temporal lobectomy:

  • Memory impairment
  • Visual loss: Contralateral superior quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky)

Other epilepsy surgery:

  • Corpus callosotomy
  • Functional hemispherectomy
  • Multiple subpial transections
  • Vagal stimulation

Related Pearl: Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy

Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy shows a familial inheritance and begins in childhood. It presents as focal seizures with a remitting and relapsing course. It is associated with:

  • Aura
  • Complex automatism
  • Post-ictal confusion
  • Anterograde amnesia

EEG findings include temporal spikes, and MRI shows hippocampal sclerosis. Management includes anteromedial resection of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A patient with Parkinson's disease has been scheduled to undergo deep brain stimulation. What is the target site for this procedure?

choices.text: Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus internus
Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus externus
Substantia nigra pars compacta and globus pallidus externus
Substantia nigra pars reticulata and globus pallidus internus

questions.solution:
The target site for deep brain stimulation in Parkinson’s disease is the subthalamic nucleus (STN) and globus pallidus internus (GPi).

It helps improve tremors and reduce both 'off' time and dyskinesia. It does not improve features that fail to respond to levodopa. It does not prevent the development or progression of non-dopaminergic features such as freezing, falling, and dementia.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who has been operated on for craniopharyngioma presents with polyuria and polydipsia. On investigation, the serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 250 mOsm/kg.  The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) level is normal. What could be the cause?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ↑serum osmolality and ↓urinary osmolality, after a cranial surgery, suggests a diagnosis of post-surgical central diabetes insipidus (DI). Irreversible central DI follows most cases of complete resections of craniopharyngioma.

Serum osmolality of >295 mOsm/L (normal: 280-295 mOsm/L) and the urine osmolality of <300 mOsm/L (normal: 500-850mOsm/L) are suggestive of DI. A water deprivation test is done to further classify the types of DI.  

Option A: In postoperative patients, because of IV fluids there is an acute expansion of ECF volume. This suppresses high ADH activity and causes diuresis with normal serum osmolality.

Option B: In SIADH, serum osmolality is decreased.

Option D: In cerebral salt-wasting syndrome there is hypersecretion ANP and their levels are usually elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about headache?

choices.text: The most common primary headache is tension type.
Indomethacin is the treatment of choice for paroxysmal hemicrania.

questions.solution:
Pial veins are not pain-producing.

Non-pain producing cranial structures include the ventricular ependyma, choroid plexus, pial vein, and a considerable portion of the brain parenchyma.

Pain-producing cranial structures include the scalp, middle meningeal artery, dural sinuses, falx cerebri, and the proximal segments of the large pial arteries.

Other options:

  • Tension-type headache is the most common type of primary headache. It is characterized by bilateral tight, bandlike discomfort. It can be episodic or chronic (>15 days per month). Nervous tension is not a proven etiology. Amitriptyline is the only proven treatment.
  • Glaucoma may present with a prostrating headache. It may be associated with nausea and vomiting. The headache often starts with severe eye pain. The affected eye is often red with a fixed and moderately dilated pupil.
  • Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) is characterized by unilateral, very severe pain; short-lasting attacks (2-45 mins); very frequent attacks (usually more than 5 times a day); marked autonomic features (lacrimation and nasal congestion) ipsilateral to the pain; rapid course (< 72 hours). Indomethacin is the treatment of choice as it can completely supress attacks of PH.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding depression?

choices.text: Major depression is more common in left-hemisphere strokes.
SSRIs may reduce fasting plasma glucose.
Depression in cancer patients is primarily due to cachexia.
Treatment of chronic hepatitis C with interferon-alpha may worsen depression.

questions.solution:
Depression in cancer patients is not primarily due to the effects of cachexia. This is evident from the fact that the prevalence of depression is higher in patients with pancreatic cancer than in patients with advanced gastric cancer (where cachexia is more prominent).

Other options:

  • Major depression (post-stroke depression) is more common in dominant hemisphere strokes. In particular, when the lesion involves the dorsolateral-frontal complex.
  • Treatment of depression in diabetic patients may be complicated by the effects of antidepressants on glycemic control. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) can induce hypoglycemia. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) can cause hyperglycemia and carbohydrate craving. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may reduce fasting plasma glucose. However, SSRIs are easier to use and are more likely to improve dietary and medication compliance.
  • Depression is common in patients with chronic hepatitis C patients, which may worsen with interferon-alpha treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with Parkinson disease (PD) is the best candidate for deep brain stimulation (DBS)?

choices.text: A 64-year-old woman on levodopa-carbidopa who continues to experience episodes of freezing while walking
A 71-year-old man with worsening symptoms of dementia
A 70-year-old woman with tremors unresponsive to dopaminergic therapy
All of the above are suitable for DBS

questions.solution:
A 70-year-old woman with tremors unresponsive to dopaminergic therapy is the best candidate for deep brain stimulation (DBS). DBS is primarily indicated for patients with severe tremors or those who have disability from levodopa-induced motor complications that cannot be controlled with medications.

DBS is the most common surgical therapy performed for PD. In this, an electrode is usually placed into a target area, typically the subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus pars interna.

DBS does not improve features of PD that fail to respond to levodopa and does not prevent the development or progression of nondopaminergic features such as freezing, falling, and dementia.

Nucleus accumbens or subgenual area 25 are targets for DBS in severely depressed patients.

DBS can also be used in primary (DYT1) dystonia.

questions.text: The term "psychiatry" was coined by _________.
questions.solution: The term "psychiatry" was coined by the German physician Johann Christian Reil in 1808.

questions.text: According to Jean Piaget’s stages of intellectual development, the concept of reversibility develops in the _______ stage.
questions.solution:
A child develops the concept of reversibility (i.e., events or ideas can be reversed) during the concrete operations stage of intellectual development. As such, a child who has not attained the concrete operation stage i.e. A child still in preoperational stage cannot understand the fact that broken bones can be mended or blood lost can be replaced.

There are 4 stages in the cognitive development stages, through which the thinking process of an individual develops. They are as follows:

Sensorimotor stage (birth–2 years):

  • Starts with "out of sight, out of mind" type of thinking
  • Ends with object permanence (knowing an object exists even though it cannot be seen) and
  • Symbolization (developing mental symbols and words for the objects).

Pre-operational stage (2-7 years):

Thinking without reasoning—intuitive thinking and

  • Only concerned about their own needs and perspective—egocentric thinking
  • Other thinking processes seen are animism, primitive thinking, centration, magical thinking

Concrete operational stage (7-11 years):

  • Start to see things from others perspective ("theory of mind")
  • Thinking is concrete and literal.
  • Develop conservation: understanding that despite changes in shape, the object remains the same, for e.g., when water is transferred from a cup to glass, they understand that it is water only and that the volume is the same.
  • Develop the concept of reversibility: knowing that one thing can turn into another and turn back. e.g.: water and ice
  • Other processes: classification, transitivity.

Formal operational stage (>11 years):

  • Develop abstract thinking, wherein they can generalize or conceptualize
  • Can make a hypothesis and use deductive reasoning

questions.text: A person with reward dependence temperament trait will have descriptors scores of  ________.
questions.solution:
Reward dependence suggests a behavior pattern in response to cues of social reward. As such, people with reward dependence temperament trait will score high on sentimental and low on detached descriptor scores.

High reward dependence is associated with increased thalamic activity and decreased 3-methoxy-4-hydroxyphenyglycol (MHPG). The individuals are kind- hearted, sensitive, socially dependent, and sociable.

Individuals low on reward dependence are practical, tough-minded, cold, insensitive, and indifferent if alone.

 

It is remarkable to note that these four temperaments can be seen as a modern interpretation of the ancient Greek temperaments, according to the Unani system of medicine: Melancholic (harm avoidance), choleric (novelty seeking), sanguine (reward dependence), and phlegmatic (persistence).

questions.text: Treatment of choice for histrionic personality disorder is ________.
questions.solution:
Psychoanalytically oriented psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for histrionic personality disorder. Pharmacotherapy can be used as an adjunctive for targeting specific symptoms (e.g. SSRIs for co-morbid depression).

Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP) and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various types of psychotherapy used, especially, for the treatment of borderline personality disorder.

While psychotherapy remains the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder, there is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

questions.text: The processes by which latent dream content is transformed into manifest dream is described as _______.
questions.solution:
Dream work is described by Freud as the unconscious mental operations by which latent dream content (unconscious thoughts and wishes that threaten to awaken the dreamer) is transformed into manifest dream content (dream that is recalled by the dreamer).

Other options:

  • Diffusion, the opposite of condensation, is a process by which a single unconscious wish is represented through multiple images in the manifest dream content.
  • Condensation is the mechanism by which several unconscious wishes, impulses, and thoughts are combined into a single image in the manifest dream content.
  • According to Freud, the dream censor acts as a guardian between the unconscious part and the preconscious part of the mind. It removes the unconscious thoughts during conscious states. But, during sleep, it allows certain unconscious content to pass through, but only after the transformation of these unconscious wishes into disguised forms (via symbolic association), which are then experienced in manifest dream content. Dream work contributes to this process.

questions.text: All of the following defense mechanisms are neurotic except ________.
questions.solution:
Introjection is an immature defence mechanism.

Narcissistic-psychotic defences:

  • Projection (psychotic)
  • Denial
  • Distortion

Immature defences:

  • Acting out
  • Blocking
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Introjection
  • Passive-aggressive behavior
  • Projection (non-psychotic)
  • Regression
  • Schizoid fantasy
  • Somatization

Neurotic defences:

  • Controlling
  • Displacement
  • Dissociation
  • Exterternalization
  • Inhibition
  • Intellectualization
  • Isolation
  • Rationalization
  • Reaction formation
  • Repression
  • Sexualization

Mature defences:

  • Altruism
  • Anticipation
  • Asceticism
  • Humor
  • Sublimation
  • Suppression

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning book Gandhi’s Truth: On the Origins of Militant Nonviolence was written by ______.
questions.solution:
The book, Gandhi’s Truth: On the Origins of Militant Nonviolence was written by Erik Erikson. It explores how Gandhi succeeded in mobilizing the Indian people both spiritually and politically as he became the revolutionary innovator of militant non-violence and India became the motherland of large-scale civil disobedience. It is hailed as one of the greatest psychosexual historical studies.

Other contributions of Erik Erikson include the following:

  • Theory of psychosocial development
  • Introduced the term "Identity crisis’’
  • Author of other famous books such as Identity: Youth and Crisis, Young Man Luther, and Childhood and Society.

Other options:

  • Karl Abraham, a German psychoanalyst, elaborated Freud’s stages of psychosexual development and postulated that obsessional neurosis resulted from fixation at the anal-sadistic phase and depression from form fixation at the oral stage.
  • Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud, elaborated on individual defense mechanisms and greatly contributed to the field of psychoanalysis, especially child psychoanalysis.
  • Carl Gustav Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist, formed the psychoanalytic school of analytic psychology and described the introvert and extrovert types of personality.

questions.text: The process by which painful repressed material is brought back to consciousness is known as ______.
questions.solution:
Abreaction is the process by which painful repressed material or conflict is brought back to consciousness. The person not only recalls but also relives the material. It is followed by an appropriate emotional response. Insight usually results from the experience.

Other options:

  • Catharsis is the expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed material that is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient.
  • Insight is the conscious awareness and understanding of one's own psychodynamics and symptoms of maladaptive behavior.
  • Undoing is a unconscious primitive defence mechanism, repetitive in nature, by which a person symbolically acts out in reverse something unacceptable that has already been done or against which the ego must defend itself. Commonly seen in obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely outcome for an alcoholic after an episode of heavy drinking?
questions.solution:
After an episode of heavy drinking, a person is more likely to be slightly overhydrated than dehydrated.

Ethanol inhibits the secretion of vasopressin at rising blood alcohol concentrations and stimulates the secretion of vasopressin at falling blood alcohol concentrations. This results in a slightly overhydrated state.

Other hormonal effects of ethanol include:

  • Increase in cortisol levels
  • Decrease in serum T3 and T4 levels

questions.text: A worried patient presents to the OPD for a health checkup. The previous night she went on a date and was enjoying his company. Once, he made her laugh so uncontrollably that she suddenly felt a loss of strength in her body and fell to the ground. Which of the following CSF findings would be diagnostic for her condition?
questions.solution:
The patient experienced an episode of cataplexy, which is characterized by decreased levels of hypocretin in CSF. cataplexy is sudden loss of muscle tone, such as jaw or head drop, weakness of the knees, or paralysis of all skeletal muscles with collapse. It is seen in narcolepsy.

Narcolepsy is the classical example of sleepiness caused due to CNS dysfunction of sleep mechanisms, mainly, a genetically triggered hypocretin deficit and dysfunction.

Levels of hypocretin receptor-I are undetectable in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of individuals who are HLA­ DQB 1*0602-positive (consistent with cataplexy-associated narcolepsy).

The classic form of narcolepsy (narcolepsy with cataplexy) is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms:

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

Symptoms commonly appear in the second decade of life. Strong emotions (such as laughter and anger) usually act as the trigger for cataplexy.

Pharmacotherapy remains the treatment of choice. Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, is used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and to improve psychomotor performance in narcolepsy. Besides this, imipramine and fluoxetine are also found effective in eliminating cataplexy.

questions.text: Functional imaging of patients with major depression will most likely show excessive metabolic activity in which of the following areas of the brain?
questions.solution:
Functional imaging of individuals with major depression has pinpointed excessive metabolic activity in Brodmann area 25, the subgenual prefrontal cortex, a brain region that connects to the amygdala and is thought to play a critical role in the processing of emotion-related information.

This increased metabolic activity reverses with successful antidepressant treatment. This region is also activated in normal subjects in whom sadness is induced by means of emotion-laden stimuli.

This information serves as the basis for an experimental approach to severe depression involving the use of deep-brain stimulation of the subgenual prefrontal cortex using implanted electrode.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the casualty following an episode of seizure. He says he was recently switched to a higher dose of his antipsychotic medication.  Which drug is he most likely on?
questions.solution:
The drug most likely implicated here is clozapine as it has the highest risk of precipitating seizures. It causes dose-dependent lowering of the seizure threshold.

Clozapine-associated seizures can be treated with sodium valproate.

Clozapine side effects: (Mnemonic - “Some say Clozapine has too many nasty adverse effects”)

  • Seizures
  • Sedation
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension/hypersalivation
  • Tachycardia
  • Mass increase: weight gain and increased appetite
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Agranulocytosis (neutropenia)
  • Enuresis and polyuria

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.solution:
Sleep-onset insomnia is a characteristic feature of anxiety disorder, not melancholia.

Melancholia is one of the oldest terms used in psychiatry, to describe the dark mood of depression. It is still used to refer to a state of depression characterized by:

  • Severe anhedonia
  • Early morning awakening (terminal insomnia)
  • Weight loss
  • Profound feelings of guilt (often over trivial events)

Melancholia is sometimes referred to as "endogenous depression" or depression that arises in the absence of external life stressors or precipitants.

questions.text: An anxious 45-year-old man comes to the casualty, drenched in sweat. He is constantly wiping secretions from his mouth and nose and also complains of abdominal cramps. On examination, his BP is elevated and mydriasis is seen. On further questioning, he reluctantly reveals a history suggestive of drug abuse. Which of the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with the classic symptoms of heroin withdrawal.

Heroin withdrawal:

  • Characteristic symptoms - myalgia, arthralgia, abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and sweating.
  • Signs on physical examination - restlessness, elevated heart rate and blood pressure, pupillary dilatation (mydriasis), piloerection, and yawning.

Treatment for opioid dependence:

Detoxification:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonist acts as sympatholytic and reduces the withdrawal symptoms.

Maintenance:

  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM (L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonists which reduce craving.
  • Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behavior.

questions.text: You are evaluating an elderly man who is suspected to have hypoactive delirium. Which of the following etiologies is most commonly associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Hypoactive delirium is commonly associated with hepatic and renal encephalopathies.

The hypoactive clinical subtype of delirium can often be confused with depression due to overlapping symptoms of psychomotor retardation and affect.

In delirium, however, the onset of such symptoms is more acute and is usually associated with some medical illness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty after being found lying on the street, muttering to himself, and cursing at bystanders. His MMSE score was 20. Physical examination findings are shown below. After admission, it is known that he has severe diarrhea and vomiting. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of dementia (MMSE score of 20), diarrhea, and dermatitis in sun-exposed areas like the forehead, neck (Casal's necklace), and hands are seen in vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency also known as pellagra. 

The neuropsychiatric symptoms of pellagra include apathy, irritability, insomnia, depression, and delirium.

Option A: Myxedema madness is a rare presentation of hypothyroidism characterized by depression, hypomania, and schizophrenia. Diarrhoea and vomiting are usually not seen.

Option C: Acute intermittent porphyria is characterized by periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychotic features, tachycardia. There is no photosensitivity in acute intermittent porphyria.

Option D: Thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke’s encephalopathy which manifests as an acute neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait, or can cause Korsakoff syndrome which manifests as a chronic amnestic syndrome characterized by severe anterograde amnesia and confabulation.

questions.text: As a first-year psychiatry resident, you see a case of a child with a history of repeated passage of faeces at inappropriate places. To make a diagnosis of encopresis, what should be the minimum age of this child?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of encopresis is not made until the child crosses 4 years of age.  It is an elimination disorder. 

Elimination disorders described in DSM-5 and ICD-11: 

  • Encopresis- repeated passage of faeces at inappropriate places.
  • Enuresis- repeated urination into bed or clothes. It is diagnosed after the age of 5 years.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking in short phrases. He also has difficulty in retaining new words and often uses general words like "stuff" to point to specific objects. The use of various grammatical structures is markedly below the age-expected level, but other developmental milestones are normal. He understands the language of others and plays cheerfully with his peers. No other significant history of trauma or childhood infection is present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history points towards expressive language deficits.

Features of expressive language deficits:

  • Marked impairment in the development of age-appropriate expressive language, which results in the use of verbal or sign language markedly below the expected level in view of a child's nonverbal intellectual capacity.
  • Language understanding (decoding) skills remain relatively intact.

When severe, the disorder becomes recognizable by about the age of 18 months.

  • The child fails to utter spontaneously or even echo single words or sounds.
  • Even simple words, such as "Mama" and "Dada," are absent from the child's active vocabulary.
  • The child seems to want to communicate, maintains eye contact, relates well to the mother, and enjoys games.

When the child starts speaking,

  • Articulation is often immature; numerous articulation errors occur.

By the age of 4 years,

  • Most children with expressive language disturbance can speak in short phrases, but may have difficulty retaining new words.
  • After beginning to speak, they acquire language more slowly than do most children.

questions.text: A patient on fluphenazine feels increasingly restless, agitated, and dysphoric and has a severe urge to move for the past 1 week. Which of the following can not be used in his management?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed akathisia, which is a side effect of antipsychotic medications. It is treated with propranolol, diphenhydramine (Benadryl), and benztropine. Ropinirole is not used for treatment.

Ropinirole is used in the treatment of restless leg syndrome, which resembles akathisia without a history of antipsychotic medication intake.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding anxiety and panic disorders?

choices.text: Anxiety disorders are the most prevalent psychiatric disorders worldwide.
Internalization is a principal defence mechanism of panic disorder.
Benzodiazepines are the DOC for panic disorder.

questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin tetrapeptide (CCK-4) induces panic attack by activating noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus and serotonergic neurons in the dorsal raphe. Other substances that induce panic attack include IV sodium lactate, Yohimbine (a2-antagonist), carbon dioxide inhalation.

Other options:

  • Depression is the more prevalent psychiatric disorder worldwide.
  • The principal defense mechanisms involved in panic disorder include reaction formation, undoing, somatization, and externalization.
  • Benzodiazepines are not recommended by NICE guidelines for panic disorder with or without agoraphobia as they are associated with less favorable outcomes in the long term, especially the potential for dependence, cog­nitive impairment, and abuse.
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used as the first-line treatment modality for the management of panic disorder with or without agoraphobia.
  • Combination of exposure therapy with relaxation training (as a cognitive behavior therapy [CBT] intervention) is found to be the most consistently efficacious approach to treatment for panic disorder.
  • Combined treatment with CBT and SSRIs is believed to be superior to either CBT or SSRIs alone.

questions.text: The best biomarker for tobacco smoke exposure is _______.
questions.solution:
Cotinine, the primary metabolite of nicotine, is currently considered the best biomarker for tobacco smoke exposure.

Measuring cotinine is preferable to measuring nicotine because cotinine persists longer in the body, with a plasma half-life of about 16 hours. It can be measured in serum, saliva, urine, and hair.

Cotinine is detected in the urine of passive smokers (exposure to second-hand smoke).

Active smokers almost always show cotinine levels higher than 10 ng/mL.

questions.text: What percentage of schizophrenic patients commit suicide?
questions.solution: Suicide is a major cause of death among people suffering from schizophrenia, and about 10% of the patients commit suicide.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true regarding the epidemiology of bipolar disorders?

choices.text: The lifetime prevalence of bipolar disorder is around 1%
The average age of onset of bipolar I disorder is 30 years
Prevalence is equal among both the sexes
Prevalence is higher in higher socio-economic strata

questions.solution:
The average age of onset of bipolar I disorder is 20 years, and in more than half of the cases, the onset is frequently in late adolescence.

The lifetime prevalence of bipolar disorder is 1.2% and prevalence is equal in both genders (unlike depression, which has a higher prevalence among females than males).

The prevalence of bipolar disorder is higher in higher socio-economic strata. By contrast, schizophrenia has a higher prevalence in the lower socio-economic strata.

Note: The mean age of onset of depression is 40 years.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with his first manic episode.  He was started on lithium. Four days into his admission, he experiences negativism, mutism, and stereotypic movements. Lorazepam was trialed for two days but was not effective. What is the next best treatment?
questions.solution:
Starting electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) will be the next best treatment for the given scenario.

About one-third manic patients will develop catatonic features as described by negativism, withdrawal, staring, immobility/stupor, mutism, posturing, grimacing, stereotypies, mannerisms to non-purposeful excitement, undirected combativeness, unexplained impulsive behavior, echopraxia and echolalia, motor excitement, bizarre grimacing, and waxy flexibility (among others).

The DSM-5 states that at least three of the above-mentioned manifestations must be present to include a catatonia specifier.

Patients with catatonia generally respond well to benzodiazepines, with lorazepam being the most effective. If there is not a good response with lorazepam, ECT should be strongly considered as an effective treatment for catatonia.

Other options:

  • When the diagnosis of catatonia has been made, the use of antipsychotic and/or antidepressant medications should generally be avoided. Antipsychotics can worsen catatonia due to parkinsonian side effects and can increase the risk for neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
  • A change in mood stabilizer dose or a change to another mood stabilizer has not been shown to be effective in the treatment of catatonia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with bipolar disorder comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. His condition was difficult to control and required treatment with multiple medications over the past two years. The patient says his mood has been stable with his current regimen, but for the past three months, he has had tremors primarily affecting his hands. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Lithium carbonate is most likely to cause the tremors described in the given scenario.

Tremors are a common adverse effect of lithium carbonate. They are sometimes related to peak serum lithium levels.

Dividing the dose of lithium carbonate and decreasing caffeine intake can decrease the severity of the tremors. In case of severe coarse tremors, lithium carbonate toxicity (serum lithium level greater than 2.5 mEq/L) must be ruled out.

Options A and C: Carbamazepine and lamotrigine are off-label agents used for the management of bipolar disorder, however, they do not cause tremors.

Option B: Tremors may occur as an adverse effect of gabapentin, but it is not prescribed for the management of bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the office because he has pain in his right hand. The office nurse  says the patient was irritable and reluctant to answer many intake questions, and he refused to put on an examination gown. On questioning, the patient is initially charming and smooth-talking, but after he is assured that the information he shares will not be relayed to his superior officer, he admits that he was involved in a fistfight. He says proudly that "the other guy is in a lot worse shape." This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Bipolar disorder, most recent episode hypomanic

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has antisocial personality disorder. Although the patient seems charming and ingratiating, he is aggressive and clearly exhibits disregard for social norms shows no remorse for his actions. These findings are characteristic of antisocial personality disorder.

Other options:

  • Bipolar disorder, hypomanic episode, is not the likely diagnosis because the patient has not had a manic or mixed episode nor does he seem depressed or distressed in social situations or other areas of functioning.
  • Conduct disorder is not the most likely diagnosis because there is no evidence that the patient has violated the basic rights of others (un-provoked aggression towards humans or animals, destruction of property, theft) or age-appropriate social norms or rules. Most symptoms are apparent before the age of 13 years.  However, if the individual is more than 18 years of age, conduct disorder is diagnosed only if the criteria are not met for antisocial personality disorder.
  • Oppositional defiant disorder, is not the likely to be the diagnosis because this disorder is characterized by an enduring pattern of negativistic, hostile, and defiant behaviours in the absence of serious violations of social norms or rights of others.

questions.text: You are doing an ICMR research study on the mental health of suicide survivors. Who among the following will you include?

choices.text: A 24-year-old college drop-out who attempted suicide by overdosing but survived.
A lady who witnessed a man hanging from a tree on her way back from work.
A middle-aged woman who survived suicide 10 years back and is currently serving as a counselor for depressed patients.
A 15-year-old boy whose father hung himself from a fan in their home.

questions.solution: The term "suicide survivor" refers to a person who has lost a loved one to suicide, not someone who attempted suicide but survived.
